rsa.title: RSA Encryption Visualized
rsa.intro: RSA is a public-key cryptosystem widely used for secure data transmission. Let's explore how it works, step by step.

1.title: Step 1: Choose Prime Numbers
1.description: RSA security relies on the difficulty of factoring large numbers. We start by choosing two different prime numbers, p and q.
1.security_note: ‚ö†Ô∏è In practice, these would be very large primes (hundreds of digits). We use small primes here for educational purposes.

2.title: Step 2: Calculate n (Modulus)
2.description: We multiply our two primes to get n, which is the modulus for both the public and private keys.

3.title: Step 3: Calculate œÜ(n) - Euler's Totient
3.description: Euler's totient function œÜ(n) counts how many numbers less than n are coprime to n (share no common factors except 1).

4.title: Step 4: Choose Public Exponent e
4.description: The public exponent e must satisfy: 1 < e < œÜ(n) and gcd(e, œÜ(n)) = 1

5.title: Step 5: Calculate Private Exponent d
5.description: The private exponent d is the modular multiplicative inverse of e modulo œÜ(n).

6.title: Step 6: Encrypt a Message
6.description: To encrypt a message m, we calculate: c = m^e mod n

7.title: Step 7: Decrypt the Message
7.description: To decrypt the ciphertext c, we use the private key: m = c^d mod n

crypto.title: FAQ: Crypto Basics
crypto.subtitle: Everything you wanted to know but were afraid to ask (or Google)

items.a: It's like a secret language, but for computers. Imagine writing a note to a friend that only they can read. Cryptography does the same thing, but with zeros and ones. üîê

Well, if you want to understand how the internet, banks, messengers, and basically everything related to security works - then yes, it's useful. Plus it sounds cool at parties: 'I understand cryptography' üòé
At first it seems like some magic with prime numbers. But actually it's just multiplication, division, and a bit of math. We've broken it down step by step here, so don't panic! üßÆ

items.q: Public and private keys - what's the difference?
items.a: Public key is like your mailbox address. Everyone can put something in (encrypt), but only you with the private key can open (decrypt) it. Simple and elegant! üì¨

Theoretically - yes. Practically - if you have a quantum computer the size of a planet and billions of years. For regular mortals, it's like guessing a password with a million characters. Almost impossible! üöÄ
Everywhere! HTTPS (the lock in your browser), bank cards, messengers, blockchain. If you see 'https://' - cryptography is working there. You're literally surrounded by it! üåê

items.q: Do I need to be a mathematician?
items.a: No! Basic arithmetic is enough. We explain all complex formulas in simple terms. If you can multiply numbers - you're halfway there! ‚ú®
Start with our RSA visualizer! Play with prime numbers, see how everything works. Then you can move to other algorithms. The main thing - don't be afraid to experiment! üéÆ

web3.title: FAQ: Web3 Basics
web3.subtitle: Blockchain, crypto and all that - without the boring terms

items.a: It's like the internet, but without big uncles (Google, Facebook) controlling everything. Instead - blockchain and cryptography. You own your data! üéØ

Imagine a chain of blocks (makes sense, right?). Each block contains information and is linked to the previous one. Changing something in an old block - almost impossible. It's like a book that can't be forged! üìö
Digital money that works on blockchain. Bitcoin, Ether and tons of others. Main difference - no central bank, everything works through a network of computers. üí∞

items.q: Why do I need private keys?
items.a: It's like the password to your crypto wallet. Only yours. Lost it - goodbye money. Showed it to someone - also goodbye. Keep it like the apple of your eye! üîë
When computers solve complex math problems to add a new block to the chain. They get cryptocurrency for it. Like gold mining, but digital! ‚õèÔ∏è
Not only! NFT (Non-Fungible Token) is a unique token on blockchain. Can be a picture, music, domain name, anything. Main thing - it's unique and belongs to you. üé®
Decentralized Finance - finance without banks. You can lend, borrow, trade - all through smart contracts. Banks not needed! üè¶‚ùå
A program on blockchain that executes conditions automatically. For example: 'If Alice transfers money, Bob gets access to the file'. No one can cheat! ü§ñ
Cryptography makes it very safe. But there are nuances: scammers, phishing, lost keys. Be careful, don't trust suspicious sites and keep keys securely! üõ°Ô∏è

items.q: Where do I start in Web3?
items.a: 1) Create a wallet (MetaMask, for example) 2) Learn basic concepts (blockchain, keys) 3) Start small - try a test network 4) Don't invest more than you're ready to lose! üéì

keyGame.title: Game: Find the Key Pair!
keyGame.subtitle: Match public keys with their private friends
keyGame.instructionsStep1: 1. Select one public key (top) - click on a card
keyGame.instructionsStep2: 2. Select one private key (bottom) - click on a card
keyGame.instructionsStep3: 3. If they match - pair found! If not - try another combination
keyGame.instructionsNote: Hint: Public key (e, n) and private key (d, n) are connected through the same prime numbers. The correct pair has the same n value!
keyGame.hint: Hint: public key = (e, n), private = (d, n). They're connected through prime numbers!
